Shinobu Kawai wrote:
> Hi,
> 
>  > An alternative is to write simple Learning Tests against their (live)
>  > API, then use that information to program your mocks.
> BTW, are there any good onsite documentation of Learning Tests?  The
> only ones I can find are Kent's TDDBE review pdf.

I'm not sure what you're looking for, Shinobu. A Learning Test is simply 
a test you write for code you're using. The goal is to codify your 
understanding of how that code works through tests. You have a record of 
what you've learned in the tests.

Is it worth just putting that paragraph on the web somewhere? (Other 
than in this mailing list, I mean.) Do you have other questions about 
Learning Tests? There is an example at the c2.com wiki under 
AbstractTestCases. It's a contract test that shows that one of IBM 
WebSphere's implementations of the Java Enumeration interface doesn't 
satisfy the contract correctly. That's a Learning Test that helps you 
record the fact that this class /does not/ satisfy the contract.--
